recipe_title: The Best Buttermilk-Brined Southern Fried Chicken Recipe

Hi.  How can I help you?
why do we use garlic powder and not fresh garlic?
Let me see...

Some folks shun garlic powder, saying that it's nothing like real garlic. That's true to some extent, but that doesn't mean it doesn't have its culinary uses. It's particularly effective in spice rubs and breadings, where fresh garlic would be difficult to incorporate, due to its texture. Therefore, we need garlic powder in this recipe.

Before moving on - have you ever heard of brining?
This is important to do here.
No, is it similar to marinating?

Indeed, it is!  Brining is the process by which a lean meat (most often chicken, turkey, or pork) is submerged in a saltwater solution. As the meat sits, the saltwater will slowly dissolve key muscle proteins—most notably myosin, a protein that acts as a sort of glue, holding muscle fibers together).

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Brining is the process by which a lean meat (most often chicken, turkey, or pork) is submerged in a saltwater solution.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: As the meat sits, the saltwater will slowly dissolve key muscle proteins—most notably myosin, a protein that acts as a sort of glue, holding muscle fibers together).

conversation.utterance: If you are familiar with marinating, what do you think are the effects it has on the meat?
It adds extra moisture,flavour and helps in keeping the meat tender while cooking.

Wow, seems that you're already an expert :-) You're right:  First, the ability of the meat to hold onto moisture increases.  Breading will help mitigate this effect to a degree by slowing down the transfer of energy to the meat, but a significant amount of squeezing is still going to occur regardless of how well breaded the chicken is. Myosin is one of the key proteins responsible for this squeezing action, so by dissolving it, you prevent a lot of moisture loss from taking place.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: First, the ability of the meat to hold onto moisture increases.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Breading will help mitigate this effect to a degree by slowing down the transfer of energy to the meat, but a significant amount of squeezing is still going to occur regardless of how well breaded the chicken is.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Myosin is one of the key proteins responsible for this squeezing action, so by dissolving it, you prevent a lot of moisture loss from taking place.

conversation.utterance: Second, brining alters the texture of the meat by allowing dissolved proteins to cross-link with each other. This is the main principle behind sausage making—dissolved proteins can bond with each other, creating a pleasantly bouncy, tender texture. Third, as the brine slowly works its way into the meat, it seasons it beyond just the very surface. An overnight brine will penetrate a few millimeters into the meat, giving you built-in seasoning before you ever get to the breading.

What is also really helpful is substituting the water with buttermilk. By doing this, the chicken comes out just as moist as with water brine, and it is significantly more tender as well, due to the tenderizing effects of buttermilk on food (soaking it for more than one night led to chicken that was so tender that it bordered on mush).  Finally, hitting the buttermilk with spices helps build flavor right into the surface of the bird.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Not only did the chicken come out just as moist as with water brine, it was actually significantly more tender as well, due to the tenderizing effects of buttermilk on food (soaking it for more than one night led to chicken that was so tender that it bordered on mush).

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab

conversation.utterance: What other techniques make it even crispier?

What happens quite often here is that your crust is almost rock-like in its density.  Knowing that gluten—the network of proteins formed when flour meets water—is the most likely culprit, you can minimize its formation.  First and foremost: cut the protein-rich wheat flour with cornstarch, a pure starch that adds moisture-absorbing capabilities to the breading without adding excess protein.  Replacing a quarter of the flour worked well. Adding a couple teaspoons of baking powder to the mix helped bring a bit of air to the mix, forming a crust that was lighter and crisper, with increased surface area (and we all know that more surface area = more crispness, right?).

Why do we need to heat the oven for fried chicken?
Interesting question.  Let me tell you

One last problem you often run into is the coating overcooking long before the chicken is cooked through to the center. This can be solved quite easily:  Just fry the chicken until golden brown, then transfer it to a hot oven to finish cooking at a gentler pace.  The result is chicken with a deep brown, craggy crust that's shatteringly crisp but not tough and that breaks away to meat that bursts with intensely seasoned juices underneath.

Why do the drumsticks need to be cooked until 165 degrees, 15 degrees higher than the breast?
Let me see...

Ok. So breast meat is composed mainly of what are known as fast-twitch muscles—muscles that are rarely used on a day-to-day basis, but are great for quick, powerful bursts of action. Fast-twitch muscle tends to be relatively light in color and low in connective tissue and fat. Leg meat, on the other hand, is mainly slow-twitch muscle. It's used day in and day out as the turkey walks around scratching for food. As a result, it's darker and packed with tough connective tissue. Because the two muscle structures are so massively different, they must be cooked differently to achieve ideal results. Breast meat is best when cooked to no higher than about 150°F-any higher and it dries out. On the other hand, the tough connective tissue in leg meat doesn't get tender until it gets to at least 165°F (74°C) or so.

provenance.page_title: Roasting Turkey? Throw Out Your Roasting Pan and Reach for Your Baking Stone | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Here's the real issue when it comes to roast turkey. Breast meat is composed mainly of what are known as fast-twitch muscles—muscles that are rarely used on a day-to-day basis, but are great for quick, powerful bursts of action. Fast-twitch muscle tends to be relatively light in color and low in connective tissue and fat. Leg meat, on the other hand, is mainly slow-twitch muscle. It's used day in and day out as the turkey walks around scratching for food. As a result, it's darker and packed with tough connective tissue.

provenance.page_title: Roasting Turkey? Throw Out Your Roasting Pan and Reach for Your Baking Stone | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Because the two muscle structures are so massively different, they must be cooked differently to achieve ideal results. Breast meat is best when cooked to no higher than about 150°F (66°C)—any higher and it dries out. On the other hand, the tough connective tissue in leg meat doesn't get tender until it gets to at least 165°F (74°C) or so.

User moved to section "Step 7".
Does the cold of the refrigerator help with the crispness of the chicken?

You can refrigerate the chicken overnight and fry it a second time just before eating it. This is a wonderful way to rejuvenate fried chicken leftovers (as if such a thing exists), and your chicken will end up even better on the second day.

provenance.page_title: Four Secrets to Improving Any Fried Chicken Recipe | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Fry your chicken as usual, then let it rest at room temperature for at least half an hour before frying it again. You can even chill and refrigerate the chicken overnight and fry it a second time just before eating it. This is a wonderful way to rejuvenate fried chicken leftovers (as if such a thing exists), and your chicken will end up even better on the second day.
